Dialogue.NPCText:
A wiry man fidgets nearby, his Patchwork Leather Cap askew and fingers stained with soot. Strange brass tools clatter from his apron as he mutters to himself, occasionally glancing at a pocketwatch that ticks… backward.

"Ah! You, um, you’re not from the last time… are you? Never mind. Sorry. I’m Moss Tanner, trapwright. Tinkerer. Sometimes... chronomancer? Depends on the day. Don’t mind the boots, they smoke sometimes after lunch. So, uh… do you feel any odd déjà vu, or is that just me again?"

Option.text: I’ve never met you before. Are you well?
You seem... distracted. What’s that ticking?
Is something wrong with time in Eldermoor?
I’m just here for traps and gadgets.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Moss blinks, running a trembling hand through wild hair.

"Yes, yes, of course, never met! Except… I feel like I’ve met everyone twice since Minax’s shadow crossed us. They say déjà vu is just the mind playing tricks. Or—sometimes—it’s *time* playing tricks on the mind! Heh. Sorry, nerves. Building traps makes you jumpy. Working for Halric is a fine way to grow grey before your time, too."

Option.text: What’s it like working for Halric?

Dialogue.NPCText:
Moss leans in conspiratorially.

"Halric is all stone and storms. Good man, deep down—heart’s as scarred as his boots. He trusts me with the palisade traps because, well, Thalen keeps melting the steel hinges, and Edda says my traps ‘keep the spirits entertained’—which I think is a compliment? Anyway, Halric’s got his hands full. If I can keep beasts out, maybe he’ll smile once before the world ends."

Moss grins, showing a chipped tooth.

"Thalen? That lad’s all fire and sparks—he’d forge a horseshoe in a thunderstorm if you let him. He *says* my gadgets are too clever by half, but he always borrows my tools. Edda’s different—she knows things about roots and time and what grows when it shouldn’t. She gives me tea for my ‘shakes’ and tells me to trust my instincts, even when the world skips a beat. They’re the best kind of trouble."

Option.text: You ever work with Edda’s herbs in your traps?
Ever wish you could leave Eldermoor?

Dialogue.NPCText: "Oh, Edda’s herbs are a trapwright’s secret weapon! She grows this ‘flashbark’ fungus—one whiff, and even ogres stagger. Sometimes I wonder if she’s part dryad; her garden’s always got a new surprise. Of course, some days my traps catch more rabbits than monsters. Mira says she’ll charge me double if I set off another one by the inn."

Option.text: Do you make traps for other villages too?

Dialogue.NPCText:
Moss groans, shoulders slumping.

"Let’s just say… the north fence still smells like burnt ogre hair, and Mira banned me from the kitchen after last spring’s ‘incident’ with the spring-loaded pie tin. I try to keep it quiet, but, well, not every experiment works. The important thing is—nobody’s lost a finger in a week! That’s progress, right?"

Option.text: You sound like you need an assistant.

Dialogue.NPCText: "Ha! If you know anyone who can set a rune-plate *without* reversing their eyebrows, send them my way. Sometimes I dream of teaching Mira the trade—she’s clever, but Halric would have my hide. Suppose I’m stuck with my own mistakes, until I figure out this… temporal resonance issue."

Moss hesitates, staring out at the horizon.

"Once, maybe. When I was young, I thought I’d see the floating cities, even walk the ice at Frostmere. But with Minax twisting the world and the woods alive with strange echoes, I think Eldermoor needs a few more stubborn fools who’ll set a snare and wait for dawn. Besides… if I ever left, who would keep track of all these loops?"

Option.text: Loops? You mean time is repeating here?

Dialogue.NPCText: "Traps are puzzles—problems you solve with springs, gears, and a little faith in physics. My favorite? The ‘Screeching Ratapult’—launches a decoy rat that squeals so loud, it distracts goblins for minutes. I keep meaning to patent it. If you need something more serious, well, I’m always tinkering. Got a new gadget right here…"

Option.text: Tell me about your new gadget.

Dialogue.NPCText: "Trinsic once tried to hire me for city defenses, but their Paladins don’t like surprises. Britain’s too ‘proper’ for traps—they want walls, not whirligigs. Buccaneer’s Den paid in gold, but their idea of a ‘humane snare’ is a pit full of spikes. Here, at least, folk appreciate a good bear trap. Even Aldric, though he calls me a ‘nervous squirrel’."

Moss rummages through his apron, producing a brass orb inlaid with flickering runes.

"This—this is my Temporal Anomaly Detector. It, um, hums when there’s magic out of place. Been getting stronger since Minax started ‘tinkering with time’—just ask Edda, or, actually, don’t, she’ll just make you drink root tea. Problem is, last time I tested it, the rooster crowed backwards and Mira swore she saw three dawns in one morning."

Option.text: Sounds dangerous. Has anyone been hurt?
What if it finds something this time?

Dialogue.NPCText:
Moss offers you the orb, eyes pleading.

"I need someone brave—or foolish enough—to help me calibrate it near the north woods. There’s something out there… something big. The device points right to the FlamebringerOgre’s den. If you can clear out the ogre *and* bring back a sample from the anomaly, I might finally fix this loop… or, at least, stop the chickens from speaking in riddles."

Option.text: I’ll take the gadget and hunt the ogre.
What does this ogre want with your device?
I’m not interested in time anomalies.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Moss looks sheepish.

"Not really, unless you count Mira’s headache, Halric’s missing hour of sleep, or the day Aldric hunted the same deer twice and claimed it was fate. It’s mostly harmless, I think. But if you help me, maybe we can set things right before Minax does something worse."

Option.text: I’ll try it out for you.

Dialogue.NPCText: "Then I’ll owe you—maybe the whole town will. Or, well, if time unravels and we all turn into newts, I’ll apologize after. Joking! I hope."

Moss winces.

"That ogre, Flamebringer, it’s not like the others. Glows with a burning light, shouts in tongues I don’t know—sometimes it moves like it’s skipping through moments. Edda says Minax ‘twisted its fate.’ I think the anomaly has trapped it in a loop—dangerous, yes, but also a chance to learn! Or… just a reason to run."

Option.text: I’ll handle the ogre and test your device.
I think I’ll pass on this adventure.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Moss hands you the humming device, his hands shaking slightly.

"Take it near the ogre’s lair, just past the old willow. If the runes turn violet and hum, it’s working! Bring me back anything… odd. And, please, if time starts repeating or you see two moons, just, um, run back here. Good luck, friend. Oh, and—don’t let the ogre get the device! It might make things even stranger."

Moss gestures to a battered chest of gadgets.

"I’ve got snares, caltrops, and a couple of those ‘Ratapults’ if you’re keen. Be warned, no refunds if you catch yourself instead of the beast. Eldermoor’s survival is built on sharp edges and quick wits—if you’ve got coin, I’ve got tools."
